head.title: The Excess Wing in the Dielectric Loss of Glass-Formers: A Johari-Goldstein β-Relaxation?

article.h1: The Excess Wing in the Dielectric Loss of Glass-Formers: A Johari-Goldstein β𝛽italic-beta\beta-Relaxation?

span.span: U. Schneider, R. Brand, P. Lunkenheimer, and A. Loidl
Experimentalphysik V, Universität Augsburg, D-86135 Augsburg, Germany

article.div: submitted to Phys. Rev. Lett. 05.01.2000; revised 02.03.2000

div.p: Dielectric loss spectra of glass-forming propylene carbonate and glycerol at temperatures above and below Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g} are presented. By performing aging experiments lasting up to five weeks, equilibrium spectra below Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g} have been obtained. During aging, the excess wing, showing up as a second power law at high frequencies, develops into a shoulder. The results strongly suggest that the excess wing, observed in a variety of glass formers, is the high-frequency flank of a β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation.

In the frequency-dependent dielectric loss, ε⁢"⁢(ν)𝜀"𝜈italic-varepsilon " OPEN:( italic-nu CLOSE:)\varepsilon"(
u), of many glass-formers, an excess contribution to the high-frequency power law of the α𝛼italic-alpha{m\alpha}-peak, ε⁢"∼ν-βsimilar-to𝜀"superscript𝜈𝛽italic-varepsilon " RELOP:similar-to italic-nu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\varepsilon"\sim
u^{- eta}, shows up about 2-3 decades above the α𝛼italic-alpha{m\alpha}-peak frequency νpsubscript𝜈𝑝italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{p}. This excess wing can be reasonably well described by a second power law, ε⁢"∼ν-bsimilar-to𝜀"superscript𝜈𝑏italic-varepsilon " RELOP:similar-to italic-nu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-b POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\varepsilon"\sim
u^{-b}, with b<β𝑏𝛽italic-b RELOP:less-than italic-betab< eta [1, 2, 3]. An excess contribution at high frequencies was already noted in the pioneering work of Davidson and Cole [4] and it is a common feature in glass-forming liquids without a well-resolved β𝛽italic-beta{m eta}-relaxation (see below). The physical origin of the excess wing is commonly considered as one of the great mysteries of glass physics. Despite the fact that some theoretical approaches describing the excess wing have been proposed [5], up to now there is no commonly accepted explanation of its microscopic origin. In addition, some phenomenological descriptions have been proposed [3, 6, 7]. Most successful is the so-called Nagel scaling [6], which leads to a collaps of the ε⁢"⁢(ν)𝜀"𝜈italic-varepsilon " OPEN:( italic-nu CLOSE:)\varepsilon"(
u) curves (including the excess wing) for different temperatures and various materials onto one master curve.

In various glass-formers additional relaxation processes, usually termed β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-processes, are clearly seen in the loss spectra, showing up as a shoulder or even a second peak at ν>νp𝜈subscript𝜈𝑝italic-nu RELOP:greater-than italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\nu>\nu_{p} [7, 8]. Such relaxations in supercooled liquids without intramolecular degrees of freedom were systematically investigated already three decades ago by Johari and Goldstein [8] and basically were ascribed to intrinsic relaxation phenomena of the glass-forming process. We recall that these Johari-Goldstein β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxations are fundamentally different from β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxations due to intramolecular degrees of freedom. Commonly it is assumed that the excess wing and β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxations are different phenomena [6, 7] and even the existence of two classes of glass-formers was proposed - ”type A” with an excess wing and ”type B” with a β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-process [7]. Based on experimental observations it seems natural to explain Johari-Goldstein β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-processes and excess wing phenomena on the same footing. Indeed such a possibility was already considered earlier [1, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13] and from an experimental point of view, it cannot be excluded that the excess wing is simply the high-frequency flank of a β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-peak, hidden under the dominating α𝛼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}-peak.

However, only the presence of a shoulder with a downward curvature can provide an unequivocal proof for an underlying β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-peak. In materials with a well pronounced β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-peak, the α𝛼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}- and β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation timescales increasingly separate with decreasing temperature. Therefore, within this picture it may be expected that at low temperatures the excess wing transfers into a shoulder, due to less interference with the α𝛼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}-peak. In marked contrast to this prediction, for various glass-forming liquids far below the glass temperature Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g}, ε⁢"⁢(ν)𝜀"𝜈italic-varepsilon " OPEN:( italic-nu CLOSE:)\varepsilon"(\nu) follows a well-developed power law, without any indication of a shoulder [1, 7]. However, measurements of glass-forming materials at low temperatures near or below Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g} suffer from the fact that thermodynamic equilibrium is not reached in measurements using usual cooling rates. In addition, the loss becomes very low yielding increasingly high experimental uncertainties. Clearly, high-precision equilibrium measurements are necessary to investigate the ”true” behavior of the excess wing at low temperatures.

Therefore we performed high-precision dielectric measurements keeping the sample at a constant temperature, some KKK{\rm K} below Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g}, for up to five weeks which ensured that thermodynamic equilibrium was indeed reached. The experiments were performed on two prototypical glass-formers known to exhibit well pronounced excess wings, propylene carbonate (PC, Tg≈159⁢Ksubscript𝑇𝑔159Kitalic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:159 KT_{g}\approx 159~{}{\rm K}) and glycerol (Tg≈185⁢Ksubscript𝑇𝑔185Kitalic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:185 KT_{g}\approx 185~{}{\rm K}). For the measurements, parallel plane capacitors having an empty capacitance up to 100⁢pF100pFNUMBER:100 pF100~{}{\rm pF} were used. Due to the approach of the fictive [14] towards the real temperature during aging, a thermal contraction of the sample may occur. Its magnitude in one dimension can be estimated to Δ⁢l/l≤3×10-3Δ𝑙𝑙3superscript103Delta italic-l MULOP:divide italic-l RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:3 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta l/l\leq 3\times 10^{-3}, which has a negligible effect on the results. High-precision measurements of the dielectric permittivity in the frequency range 10-4⁢Hz≤ν≤106⁢Hzsuperscript104Hz𝜈superscript106HzNUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Hz RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-nu RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Hz10^{-4}~{}{\rm Hz}\leq\nu\leq 10^{6}~{}{\rm Hz} were performed using a Novocontrol alpha-analyser. It allows for the detection of values of tan⁡δ𝛿TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-delta\tan\delta as low as 10-4superscript104NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end10^{-4}. At selected temperatures and aging times, additional frequency sweeps at 20⁢Hz≤ν≤1⁢MHz20Hz𝜈1MHzNUMBER:20 Hz RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-nu RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:1 MHz20~{}{\rm Hz}\leq\nu\leq 1~{}{\rm MHz} were performed with the autobalance bridges Hewlett-Packard HP4284 and HP4285. To keep the samples at a fixed temperature for up to five weeks, a closed-cycle refrigerator system was used. The

img.figcaption: Figure 1: Frequency-dependent dielectric loss of PC (a) and glycerol (b) for different aging times t𝑡italic-tt (not all shown). The lines connect the symbols for t≤106⁢s𝑡superscript106sitalic-t RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end st\leq 10^{6}~{}{\rm s}. The spectra for the maximum aging time of 106.5⁢ssuperscript106.5sNUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6.5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end s10^{6.5}~{}{\rm s} (□□square\square) have been taken in an extended frequency range.

div.p: sample was cooled from a temperature 20⁢K20KNUMBER:20 K20~{}{\rm K} above Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g} with the maximum possible cooling rate of about 3⁢K/min3KminNUMBER:3 K MULOP:divide min3~{}{\rm K/min}. The final temperature was reached without any temperature undershoot. As zero point of the aging times reported below, we took the time when the desired temperature was reached, about 200⁢s200sNUMBER:200 s200~{}{\rm s} after passing Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g}. The temperature was kept stable within 0.02⁢K0.02KNUMBER:0.02 K0.02~{}{\rm K} during the five weeks measurement time.

Figure 1 shows ε⁢"⁢(ν)𝜀"𝜈italic-varepsilon " OPEN:( italic-nu CLOSE:)\varepsilon"(\nu) of PC and glycerol at temperatures some KKK{\rm K} below Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g} during aging. A strong dependence of the spectra on aging time t𝑡italic-tt is observed. The spectra measured after the maximum time of t=106.5⁢s𝑡superscript106.5sitalic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6.5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end st=10^{6.5}~{}{\rm s} (squares) are identical to those obtained after t=106⁢s𝑡superscript106sitalic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end st=10^{6}~{}{\rm s} (stars), clearly demonstrating that equilibrium was reached. In Fig. 2 these equilibrium spectra are shown, together with equilibrium curves taken at higher temperatures, partly published earlier [15]. Obviously, in the frequency window of Fig. 1 mainly the excess wing region is covered; the α𝛼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}-peak is located at much lower frequencies, leading to a somewhat steeper increase towards low frequencies only. In Fig. 1 for both materials indeed the typical power law, characteristic of an excess wing, is observed for short t𝑡italic-tt. However, with increasing t𝑡italic-tt the excess wing successively develops into a shoulder! This behaviour strongly suggests that a relaxation is the origin of the excess wing observed at shorter times or

img.figcaption: Figure 2: Frequency-dependent dielectric loss of PC (a) and glycerol (b) for different temperatures. All curves were taken in thermodynamic equilibrium.

div.p: higher temperatures (Fig. 2). Admittedly, for glycerol the curvature in log10⁡ε⁢"⁢(log10⁡ν)subscript10𝜀"subscript10𝜈OPFUNCTION:logarithm POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:10 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-varepsilon " OPEN:( OPFUNCTION:logarithm POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:10 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-nu CLOSE:)\log_{10}\varepsilon"(\log_{10}\nu) is quite subtle (Fig. 1b). However, further evidence is provided by Fig. 3 where the derivatives of the lowest curves in Figs. 1 and 2 are shown. A maximum is observed, clearly indicative of a β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-process [7]. In the region of the shoulder, the values of tan⁡δ𝛿TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-delta\tan\delta ranging between 5×10-35superscript103NUMBER:5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end5\times 10^{-3} and 2×10-22superscript102NUMBER:2 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end2\times 10^{-2} are well above the resolution limits of the measurement. In addition, for both materials measurements using the autobalance bridges (not shown) agree well with those obtained with the alpha-analyser. Finally, the response of the empty capacitor was measured at the temperatures of Fig. 1. The resulting loss of ε⁢"<1.5×10-4𝜀"1.5superscript104italic-varepsilon " RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1.5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\varepsilon"<1.5\times 10^{-4} in the region of 10⁢Hz≤ν≤100⁢kHz10Hz𝜈100kHzNUMBER:10 Hz RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-nu RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:100 kHz10~{}{\rm Hz}\leq\nu\leq 100~{}{\rm kHz} excludes a non-intrinsic origin of the observed shoulder.

The results of Fig. 1 are interpreted as follows: During aging the fictive temperature [14] successively approaches the ”real” temperature leading to a strong shift of the α𝛼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}-peak towards lower frequencies. The relaxation times of β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-processes usually exhibit a weaker temperature dependence than those of the α𝛼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}-process. Therefore the β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-process causing the excess wing can be expected to be less affected by the aging. The different aging depencences of the α𝛼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}- and the β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-process can also easily be deduced from the fact that the spectra at different aging times cannot be scaled onto each other by a horizontal shift in Fig. 1. In addition, aging experiments reported by Johari and

img.figcaption: Figure 3: Derivative of the dielectric loss spectra obtained after 106.5⁢ssuperscript106.5sNUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6.5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end s10^{6.5}~{}{\rm s}. The lines correspond to the fits shown in Fig. 4.

div.p: coworkers [8] revealed a negligible change of the β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-peak frequency with aging time [16]. Overall, with increasing aging time, respectively decreasing effective temperature, the time scales of α𝛼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}- and β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-process become successively separated and finally the presence of a β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation is revealed by the appearence of a shoulder.

A close inspection of dielectric measurements at low temperatures, reported in literature, reveals some further evidence of a β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation being the origin of the excess wing: Already in the spectrum obtained by Leheny and Nagel [17] after aging of glycerol for 2.5×106⁢s2.5superscript106sNUMBER:2.5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end s2.5\times 10^{6}~{}{\rm s} at 177.6⁢K177.6KNUMBER:177.6 K177.6~{}{\rm K} a vague indication for a shoulder is present. However, possibly due to doubt of its significance, these authors payed no attention to this feature. In addition, in various other published results, near or just below Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g} some indications for a shoulder show up [1, 3, 13, 15, 18], again being ignored in most of these publications. Except for [13] the thermal history was not reported in detail and it can be doubted if thermal equilibrium was reached. In the study of Wagner and Richert [13], in highly quenched Salol a strong secondary peak appeared below Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g} which vanished after heating to Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g}. In addition, in isochronal measurements of various quenched glass-formers [19] non-equilibrium secondary relaxations were detected. From the results in [13, 19] the question arises if the subtle indications for a β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation seen around Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g} in [1, 3, 13, 15, 18] are pure non-equilibrium effects and if this relaxation may completely vanish in equilibrium. Only the present aging experiments could prove that the excess wing is due to a β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation that is an equilibrium phenomenon. In Fig. 1 the amplitude of the β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-peak (only seen as excess wing at short times) may be suspected to diminish with aging. Interestingly, in systems with well resolved β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxations a similar behavior was observed [8, 9]. Finally it should be mentioned that in [20] evidence of a β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation in various systems without a clearly resolvable second relaxation peak (including PC) was found by using a ”difference isochrone” method.

img.figcaption: Figure 4: Dielectric loss spectra obtained after 106.5⁢ssuperscript106.5sNUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6.5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end s10^{6.5}~{}{\rm s}. The solid lines are fits with a sum of a CD (dashed line) and a CC function (dash-dotted).

div.p: In addition, in glycerol a high-frequency shoulder was detected by performing high-pressure dielectric experiments [21]. Further evidences for β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxations in typical excess-wing glass-formers have also been obtained from other experimental methods, e.g. calorimetry [23] or nuclear magnetic resonance [24]. A strong corroboration of the present results is also provided by our recent results in ethanol, which prove that the well-pronounced excess wing in this glass-former is also due to a β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation [22].

What further information on the β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation causing the excess wing can be gained from the present data? The α𝛼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}-peaks in PC and glycerol can well be fitted using the empirical Cole-Davidson (CD) function [4, 15]. In materials with well pronounced β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-peaks their spectral shape often can be described by the Cole-Cole (CC) function [25]. In Fig. 4 we demonstrate that the equilibrium curves of Fig. 1 can well be fitted using a sum of a CD and a CC function. Similar analyses were performed in [1, 10, 11, 12]. In Fig. 3 the corresponding derivatives are shown – again a reasonable agreement can be stated. In the same way also the present spectra at higher temperatures (Fig. 2) can be described [26]. The resulting characteristics of the β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxations in PC and glycerol can be summarized as follows: i) The relaxation strength increases with T𝑇italic-TT. This is often found for well resolved β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxations, e.g. in [7]. ii) The width of the relaxation peaks becomes smaller with T𝑇italic-TT, which is also a common property of well separated β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxations [7] iii) Despite some difficulty to obtain precise information on the temperature development of the β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation time, τβsubscript𝜏𝛽italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{\beta}, the analysis reveals significant deviations from thermally activated behavior [26]. Therefore one may have objections using the term ”β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation” in this case, as they are commonly assumed to follow an Arrhenius behavior. However, there is no principle reason that β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-processes always should behave thermally activated, especially as their microscopic origin is still unclear. Already Johari [8] suspected that in systems without a well resolved β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-process, the relaxation times of α𝛼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}- and β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-process are closer together due to an uncommon temperature dependence of τβsubscript𝜏𝛽italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{\beta}. Maybe the only difference between ”type A” and ”type B” glass-formers in the classification scheme of [7] is just the temperature evolution of the β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-dynamics: In the latter materials it is thermally activated, leading to a clear separation of α𝛼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}- and β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-peak at low temperatures. In contrast, in ”type A” materials τβ⁢(T)subscript𝜏𝛽𝑇italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-T CLOSE:)\tau_{\beta}(T) follows more closely τα⁢(T)subscript𝜏𝛼𝑇italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-T CLOSE:)\tau_{\alpha}(T) (i.e., it deviates from Arrhenius) and only the high-frequency flank of the β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-peak – the excess wing – is visible. The Nagel-scaling [6], which strongly suggests a correlation between the α𝛼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}-process and the excess wing in ”type A” systems, is not opposed to this framework: It simply implies that in those materials the parameters characterizing both relaxation processes are intimately related.

In this context it is of interest that recently for ”type B” glass-formers a correlation of τβsubscript𝜏𝛽italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{\beta} and the Kohlrausch-exponent βK⁢W⁢Wsubscript𝛽𝐾𝑊𝑊italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K italic-W italic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\beta_{KWW} (describing the width of the α𝛼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}-peak), both at Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g}, was found [27]: logτβ10⁢(Tg)subscriptsubscript𝜏𝛽10subscript𝑇𝑔FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:10 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:){}_{10}\tau_{\beta}(T_{g}) increases monotonically with βK⁢W⁢W⁢(Tg)subscript𝛽𝐾𝑊𝑊subscript𝑇𝑔italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K italic-W italic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\beta_{KWW}(T_{g}). It was noted that those glass-formers that show no well-resolved β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation (including PC and glycerol) have relatively large values of βK⁢W⁢W⁢(Tg)subscript𝛽𝐾𝑊𝑊subscript𝑇𝑔italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K italic-W italic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\beta_{KWW}(T_{g}). As the mentioned correlation implies that the α𝛼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}- and β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-timescales approach each other with increasing βK⁢W⁢W⁢(Tg)subscript𝛽𝐾𝑊𝑊subscript𝑇𝑔italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K italic-W italic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\beta_{KWW}(T_{g}), the unobservability of a shoulder in those materials is easily rationalized. In [27] an explanation of this behavior within the coupling model (CM) [28] was proposed. Recently it was shown that the Nagel-scaling can be explained within this framework [11] and even the deviation of τβ⁢(T)subscript𝜏𝛽𝑇italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-T CLOSE:)\tau_{\beta}(T) from thermally activated behavior seems to be consistent with the CM.

In summary, by performing high-precision measurements below Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g} in thermodynamic equilibrium we were able to resolve the presence of β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxations in two typical excess wing glass-formers. Our results strongly suggest that the so-far mysterious excess wing, showing up at higher temperatures, is simply the high-frequency flank of the loss-peaks caused by these β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxations. Of course, the mere identification of the excess wing with a β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation provides no explanation, e.g. for the Nagel scaling [6] or the question why glass-formers seem to fall into two classes - those with a well-separated β𝛽italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation and those without [7]. But the knowledge of the true nature of the excess wing certainly is a prerequisite for any microscopic explanation of these phenomena, (e.g. [11, 27]) and hopefully will enhance our understanding of the glass transition in general.
We thank K.L. Ngai for stimulating dicussions. This work was supported by the DFG, Grant-No. LO264/8-1 and partly by the BMBF, contract-No. EKM 13N6917.
